questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from Brazil arrives at a major international airport in India. She is scheduled to travel to various rural areas in India for a pilgrimage. She is in good health and has no history of recent illnesses. As the airport's medical officer reviewing her health documentation, you note that she has completed most recommended vaccinations for travel. Considering her origin and travel plans, which of the following vaccination certificates is most important to verify for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Yellow fever

 

Option D:

 

Yellow fever is a viral disease endemic in tropical areas of Africa and South America. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends yellow fever vaccination for travelers coming from countries where yellow fever is endemic, like Brazil, especially when they are traveling to other countries where the disease might not be endemic but the mosquito vector (Aedes aegypti) is present, like India.

 

International measures to restrict the spread of Yellow Fever (IHRs):

 

Travelers - 

 

  • Validity of Yellow fever vaccination certificate - Lifelong.
  • If no such certificate available: Quarantine for 6 days (Max, I.P of YF) from date of leaving an infected area
  • If traveller arrives before certificate becomes valid (10 days after vaccination): Isolate till it becomes valid

 

Mosquitoes:

 

  • Aircrafts/ships arriving from endemic areas: Aerosol spray to kill insect vectors
  • Airports/seaports kept free from vector breeding: at least 400 meters around boundary
  • Aedes aegypti index: kept below 1%

 

Breteau Index (Aedes aegypti index) should be <1% in towns and seaports in endemic areas to ensure freedom from Yellow Fever


Vaccine: 17D strain -

 

  • It can be given from 9 months, valid after 10 days of the vaccination for lifetime.
  • YF vaccine is the only live vaccine that can be administered in Pregnancy (if there is risk of exposure).
  • Contraindicated during Lactation and in cases of Egg allergy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A vaccination is generally recommended for travelers to areas with high endemicity. It's not specifically required for entry into India.

 

Option B. BCG: It's not a standard travel vaccine.

 

Option C. Japanese Encephalitis: This vaccine is recommended for travelers to Asia who will be spending a lot of time outdoors in rural areas, but it's not a standard requirement for entry into India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • India is a ‘Yellow Fever receptive’ area: Population is unvaccinated and susceptible to Yellow Fever. 
  • Under IHR Travellers must possess a valid International certificate of vaccination (validity 10 days–Lifelong) against YF before they enter ‘YF receptive areas’

 

Ref: PARK 26th ed 324
